node.title: Oh, God, Guns. Still Guns.
node.description: Who would have thought a locked drawer could loom so large?
node.content: ["Americans who try to keep track of what\u2019s going on in Congress frequently fall back on a cry of Why don\u2019t they just. \u2026", "It comes up when there\u2019s an apparently endless string of crises that appear to have simple, at least partial solutions.", "So why don\u2019t they just. \u2026", "The answer is almost never satisfactory. Obscure rules. Joe Manchin. Congressional Budget Office report still pending.", "One good, terrible example is mass shootings. It\u2019s easy to throw your hands up in despair \u2014 our lawmakers should have spent a lot more time trying to avoid disasters like that hideous school blood bath in Michigan. The shooter was a student, using a gun that his parents had given him as a present. Mom and Dad are charged with involuntary manslaughter by a wildly frustrated prosecutor, but it\u2019s hard to tell if this will work.", "Still, whether the charges stick or not, it\u2019s clear the parents were the problem. \u201cLOL, I\u2019m not mad at you. You have to learn not to get caught,\u201d Jennifer Crumbley texted her son after a teacher found him looking at ammunition online.", "Jennifer and her husband, James, seemed to believe that sharing weaponry with your son was a great way of bonding. According to prosecutors, Ethan Crumbley, 15, got a gun from a drawer in his parents\u2019 bedroom \u2014 Michigan is among the majority of states that don\u2019t have enough rules requiring secure storage. And very soon, four of his fellow students were dead.", "Guns, often loaded, are left lying around a terrifying number of homes. Why doesn\u2019t Congress at least pass a law requiring they be kept under lock and key?", "Well, it\u2019s not as if nobody thought about it. \u201cI\u2019m really trying to seize the moment,\u201d said Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut. Whenever terrible gun issues come up, it\u2019s a good idea to talk to the lawmakers from Connecticut, where, back in 2012, a former student killed 20 first graders and six educators at a school in Newtown.", "Many, many Americans remember the Newtown shooting \u2014 how they felt when they heard about it and, possibly, the confident expectation that this horror would mean the beginning of powerful gun safety legislation.", "Nah. And Blumenthal says that so far he\u2019s still \u201cnowhere near\u201d the 60 votes needed in the Senate to overcome a Republican filibuster and pass a bill mandating safe storage.", "Opponents, to the degree that they bother to justify themselves at all, say that if all guns were locked up, owners might not be able to get their hands on their weapons fast enough in case murderous intruders broke into their home.", "\u201cThe only thing that stops a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun,\u201d snarled Wayne LaPierre, the deeply disgraced and yet still C.E.O. of the National Rifle Association.", "That\u2019s Wayne\u2019s world vision. Or you can look at it this way: Based on a study published in Preventive Medicine, guns were actually used for self-defense at home in approximately 1 percent of crimes surveyed between 2007 and 2011.", "Meanwhile, according to Everytown for Gun Safety, this year there were at least 322 unintentional shootings by children in American homes, resulting in 132 deaths and 206 injuries.", "And we\u2019ve been through hundreds of school shootings since Newtown. The only real, serious response seems to have been the education of our children in what to do when a classmate starts spraying bullets. The United States is a world leader in teaching youngsters how to duck and cover behind their desks.", "Even the modest gun regulation the country has managed to pass gets mangled, mauled and dismembered over time.", "Connecticut\u2019s other senator, Chris Murphy, has been laboring endlessly on the law requiring background checks for gun purchasers. There\u2019s a large hole in the rules when it comes to weapons bought from private sellers. \u201cI spent a lot of time earlier in the year trying to negotiate a compromise,\u201d he said. But nada.", "Last week, Murphy asked for unanimous consent for the Senate to take up his background check bill. \u201cI understand the low likelihood of success,\u201d he said \u2014 accurately, as it happens. But given the tragedy in Michigan, he thought it was the least he and his colleagues could do.", "Actually, it\u2019s always possible to do less. Senator Chuck Grassley, the Judiciary Committee\u2019s top Republican, blocked Murphy\u2019s request.", "This frustration is a very familiar story. Back in 1994 the Senate passed a ban on assault weapons \u2014 those rapid-fire guns that figure so prominently in mass shootings. It was under the leadership of one Senator Joe Biden, who allowed the inclusion of a 10-year expiration date.", "Whoops. After a decade, assault weapons came back like the swallows to Capistrano. The Arctic terns to Greenland. The gray whales to Baja. All attempts to get rid of them have flopped.", "Well, at least Biden is back in power, ready to restart a fight for real gun safety. Unfortunately, so far he hasn\u2019t even been able to get Congress to confirm a nominee to head the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.", "Or, it seems, pass a law requiring gun owners to keep their weapons stored in a safe place."]
